SummaryOfEvents:
On February 13 at 0630 NICOLAI MAERSK arrived at Ferguson Container Terminal in Auckland and berthed starboard side to. Before arrival a port side lifeboat drill was scheduled to take place immediate following the arrival and under the command of the chief officer.

At 0715 the lifeboat was ready for launching. 7 crew members were on board the lifeboat and were fastened in their seatbelt. The boat was lowered to a position level with the boat deck, and at that point the hoisting function was tested. The winch motor did not hoist and the drill was therefore abandoned and an attempt was made to hoist the boat by hand. In order to investigate the cause the electrician was sent down to the HI-press room, where the electrical panel board of the davit motor is located. By pushing different contacts at the panel board the winch motor could be brought to hoist in jerks.

Suddenly the winch started to hoist steady and fast and continued hoisting after the davits had reached their uppermost position. Due to the continued pull the wires broke and the boat fell 16 metres down to the sea. One of the crew members was so seriously injured, that he died shortly after, 3 other crew members were seriously injured and the remaining 3 crew members sustained light to moderate injuries.

The investigations following the accident has shown, that by pushing the contacts at the panel board the Proximity Cut-off Switches at the davits, which cut off the current for the winch motor just before the davits reaches their stop position, and the Over Current Control Relay, which cut off the current for the winch motor in case of overload, were bypassed.

Location: Atlantic Ocean, 80 nm W. of Butt of Lewis

SummaryOfEvents: On 26.01.2001 at 00.00 M/V "Pamiat Merkuriya" left the port of Istanbul for destination, the port of Eupatoria (Crimea, Black Sea), and was loaded with 324 mt of general cargo (instead of allowed 200 mt) including 235 mt on deck (instead of allowed 25 mt). Thus the vessel was overloaded. It had 27 crewmembers and 25 passengers onboard. The route should have been used in accordance with the GMDSS area A.1 (no more then 25 miles offshore) but the master kept route area A.2 (100 miles from offshore). Due to the overload, free spaces into the ship's tanks and loss of stability M/V "Pamyat Merkuria" listed and sunk. It happened on 26.01.2001 at 18.52 by the Ukrainian time in position 43°47'O N 31°43'0 E. As a result, 8 persons were lost and 12 persons counted as missing assumed lost.

SummaryOfEvents: For unknown reasons the BUFFALO grounded while docking at a private dock using a privately maintaned channel. Grounding resulted in hull breach and flooding to #5 starboard ballast tank. Testimony of vessel Master placed the vessel in the navigable channel. Waterway survey indicated adequate water depth for the vessel's draft. Investigation failed to arrive at a definitive conclusion as to the causal factors regarding the grounding and subsequent vessel damage.

The ULTRA CONTAINER collided with the LIBERTY SPIRIT breaching its hull at the No four cargo hold and causing major hull damage. No deaths, injuries or pollution resulted.

SummaryOfEvents: On 03 October 2000; the tug Keta V was in transit off Nova Scotia. That evening, it endeavoured to stop at Liverpool for the night. The tug headed for Moose Point, south of Liverpool Bay, and preceded toward Eastern Head, where it ran aground and then capsized and sank a short time later. The crew members were rescued. No casualties or major pollution were reported as a result of this occurrence.

SummaryOfEvents:
The tug MILLENIUM STAR, towing the container barge INVESTIGATOR from Akutan, Alaska to Dutch Harbor, Alaska grounded with resultant hull damage, flooding and pollution. During the transit the master was the only crewmember awake and on watch piloting the vessel. In the early morning hours, the Master departed the pilothouse to wake other crew members in preparation of shortening the tow prior to entering port. The tug ran aground while the master was below.
The investigation revealed that the vessel's master had fallen asleep and surmised that fatigue was the major causal factor contributing to this casualty. Prior to leaving the discharge port, the Master had assisted in the loading and securing of the barge's containers and had only gotten two hours of sleep prior to departing port. It was also found that he had only slept six hours in the previous 24 hour period prior to the grounding.

SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately 22:30 hours on Sunday the 20th August the fishing ship “Fiona Patricia” cast off from her berth at Castletownbere. All navigation equipment was reported to be in good order. According to the Skipper the ship was lined up in the white sector of Dinish Island light when he observed a small craft ahead in the channel showing a starboard navigational light.

According to the skipper of the “Fiona Patricia” as he was passing starboard to starboard, clear of the small craft, he decided to maintain course so remain in the channel.  

At approximately 23:00 hours “the Fiona Patricia” collided with the unlit barge “Montgomery”

Kinnestabben, at entrance to Langesundfjord, Norway
SummaryOfEvents:
MV BOA TRANSPORTER was entering Dypingen port on 20 June 2000. The vessel had departed from Hirtshals, Denmark, destination Brevik, Norway with 7 trailers and one car onbard. No pilot was onboard as the local Authorities had given permission to the vessel's Captain to enter the port without a pilot. Heavy fog was present at the time and the sea was calm. No equipment failure was reported.
At the time of the grounding the Captain was alone on the bridge. He intended to sail through the narrow gap between Kinnestabben and Kjoertingen. Whilst performing a manoeuvre to correct his course, the Captain reported that the wheel reacted slower than normal. He did not manage to correct his course on time and the vessel hit the rocky Kinnestabben with port side bottom and damaged the lighthouse with starboard side. Speed at time of grounding about 6 knots. Flooding in engine room occurred due to the grounding.

SummaryOfEvents:
Soon after departed from Macau for Hong Kong on its sixth trip of the day on 4 June 2000, a fire  broke  out in the starboard turbine room of the jetfoil “Terceira”. The fire was extinguished by releasing halon into the turbine room. The jetfoil later returned to Macau under the power of its port engine and with a tug boat in attendance. All passengers disembarked safely and there were no casualties.

The fire was caused by hydraulic oil spraying over the hot turbine engine casing from a burst high pressure hydraulic oil pope inside the starboard turbine room. The hydraulic oil pipe appears to have been damaged resulting from vibration

SummaryOfEvents: A faulty solenoid to the hydraulic steering gear on the M/V AMERICAN MARINER failed while the vessel  was downbound in the approach to St Clair River. The steering gear malfunctioned as the vessel was meeting aids to Navigation (ATON) numbers 7 & 8. The master called for a helm correction to get vessel on a range but the vessel not respond. Helmsman switched over to emergency steering at which time the rudder went hard to the starboard. Vessel allided with fixed ATON #7 on the starboard side causing considerable hull damage, flooding and grounding. Vessel also blocked main shipping channel closing waterway to deep draft vessels for almost a day.

SummaryOfEvents:
MV AMARANTOS departed Nantong, China on 19 March 2000 after having spent 3 weeks in a repair yard. The vessel was bound for Wallaroo to lad a cargo of wheat. AMARANTOS arrived at the anchorage off Port Wallaroo on 6 April. On 10 April the pilot embarked on AMARANTOS and the vessel headed towards its berth. Two tugs were employed to assist in the manoeuvring. 

The approach to the jetty in Wallaroo proceeded normally. When the vessel was about 200m off the jetty, drifting slowly and approaching at almost right angles to it, the pilot ordered half astern to slow the vessel down and swing it round to berth alongside the jetty. When the vessel was about 150m off the jetty and still at right angles to it, the pilot reported to have realised that the half astern movement was having little effect on the speed of the ship. So he ordered full astern and also full power to the two tugs to swing the ship round. The time of his order was about 0718.

These orders still made little progress in slowing down and swinging the ship round. When the ship was about 70m away from the jetty, the master reported to have taken initiative himself and ordered emergency full astern. However, at 0720 the vessel made contact with the Wallaroo jetty and grain loader. The AMARANTOS suffered little superficial damage. However the grain loader superstructure and jetty suffered substantial damage.

Location: Juan de Fuca Strait, British Columbia
11 miles S.-E. of the Isle of Man
SummaryOfEvents:
Following a short period spent in harbour over the New Year holiday, SOLWAY HARVESTER sailed to resume fishing on 6 January 2000.  She returned briefly to the Isle of Whithorn early in the morning of 10 January to land her catch before sailing, once again, for the scallops beds north of Wales.  By 1800 the next day, she had sunk in a position south-east of the Isle of Man.  The weather was very bad and her crew of seven drowned.
Subsequent events included a search for the wreck, and underwater survey, the recovery of the bodies by the Isle of Man Authorities and, eventually, the salvage of the vessel.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life
